title: How to Make Bruschetta

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 450°F (230°C).
Slice a baguette into ½ inch (1.27 centimeters) thick slices.
steps.description: To get the most surface area, try to slice the bread diagonally, instead of straight down.

steps.headline: Use a pastry brush to coat one side of each slice with olive oil.
steps.description: You do not need to coat both sides with olive oil. The oil will help create a "barrier" between the topping the bread, and prevent it from getting too soggy.

steps.headline: Place the slices olive oil-side-down on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Depending on how big your baking sheet is, and how many slices you have, you may need to make several batches.

steps.headline: Bake the slices on the top rack in your oven for 5 to 6 minutes.
steps.description: The rack should be about 4 to 5 inches (10.16 to 12.7 centimeters) from the heat source. When the edges turn golden brown, take them out. You can also toast them under a broiler for 3 minutes, turning once. For richer bruschetta, melt some butter in a large skillet. Heat the bread slices in the skillet on both sides until they are golden brown.

steps.headline: Arrange the bruschetta oily-side-up on a platter.
steps.description: After this point, you can start preparing the traditional tomato-basil topping, or you can use a different, more unique one.

parts.name: Making the Tomato and Basil Topping

steps.headline: Brown the garlic in a small skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Begin by heating 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a small skillet, then add 5 cloves of minced garlic. Stir, and fry the two together for 1 minute. Remove the garlic when it becomes golden, but don't like it become too brown.

steps.headline: Transfer the oil and garlic to a mixing bowl and let it cool.
steps.description: Make sure that the bowl is large enough to fit the rest of your ingredients. You will eventually be mixing everything in this bowl.

steps.headline: Cut 2 pints of red grape tomatoes into halves.
steps.description: For a more unique and colorful bruschetta topping, use 1 pint of red grade tomatoes, and 1 pint of yellow grape tomatoes.

steps.headline: Cut some basil into thin slices.
steps.description: Take a few basic leaves and stack them. Next, roll them up like a burrito and cinnamon bun. Use a sharp knife to cut the basil into thin, narrow slices. Repeat this step until you have used up all your basil leaves.

steps.headline: Add the halved tomatoes, balsamic vinegar, basil, salt, and pepper to the mixing bowl.
steps.description: For a more flavorful bruschetta, add 2 tablespoons of grated parmesan cheese.

steps.headline: Wait 1 to 2 hours.
steps.description: This will give the tomatoes enough time to absorb all the flavors.

steps.headline: Spread the tomato mixture over the bruschetta just before serving.
steps.description: Make sure that you are spreading it on the oily side; the oil will help keep the bread from getting too soggy. You can also serve the mixture in a bowl with a spoon. This way, your guests can pick up how much they want.

steps.headline: Prepare some toasted slices of baguette, then add your desired topping.
steps.description: This section will give you several different recipes for bruschetta toppings. They range from sweet to sweet n' savory, to savory.

steps.headline: Try a simple seasoning of garlic, olive oil, and salt.
steps.description: Cut a clove of garlic in half, and rub it over the oily side of the toasted bread slices. Finish off with a drizzle of olive oil and a sprinkle of salt and/or pepper.

steps.headline: Use a gorgonzola-honey topping if you like the savory-sweet.
steps.description: Spread some gorgonzola cheese over the oily side of each bread slice. Bake, broil, or grill the bread, cheesy-side-up for a few more minutes until the cheese has melted. Transfer the bruschetta slices to a platter, and drizzle each slice with honey. Serve immediately. You will need about 8 ounces (225 grams) of gorgonzola cheese and 3 tablespoons of honey. For an added crunch, add some chopped walnuts or pecans on top.

steps.headline: Use ricotta cheese and marmalade for another savory-sweet combination.
steps.description: Spread 2 tablespoons of ricotta cheese over the top of each bread slice. Add 1 tablespoon of marmalade to each slice and serve.

steps.headline: Use a classic combination of salmon and cream cheese.
steps.description: Spread some cream cheese over the bread slices, then drape a slice of salmon over each one. Finish off with a sprinkle of dill.

steps.headline: Try some prosciutto, peaches, and goat cheese for a more unique flavor.
steps.description: Spread some goat cheese onto the toasted bread slices. Place a slice of prosciutto over the cheese. Add two, thin peach slices. Finish off with a drizzle of olive oil and a pinch of sea salt. Serve immediately.

steps.headline: If you want something zesty, give ricotta cheese and lemon a try.
steps.description: In a small bowl, combine 8 ounces (225 grams) of ricotta cheese and the zest of 1 lemon. Add salt and pepper to taste and spread over the toasted bread slices. Finish off with a drizzle of honey and a sprinkle of thyme. Serve while it is still warm.

steps.headline: If you have a sweet tooth, try strawberries and sugar.
steps.description: Slice enough strawberries to cover the tops of the toasted bread slices. Generously sprinkle the strawberries with sugar. Turn on the broiler, and heat the bruschetta for about 2 minutes, or until the sugar caramelizes.
